description: The Roman Empire and the rise of Christianity posed questions about the soul, civic and religious
virtue, building and resisting empire, and the use of history for political ends. Students address
how Christianity was shaped by Roman culture and shaped it in turn. Works include epic, history,
philosophy, oratory, canonical and non-canonical gospels, epistles, and apocalyptic works.
Students practice oral presentations and debates and complete a project linking visual arts to
Roman culture and religion. Offered annually during January Term. Counts toward ancient studies
